pullRequest.body: Given any field `F`, polynomial `p : F[X]` and natural number `d`, we have defined `Polynomial.hilbertPoly p d : F[X]`. If `F` is of characteristic zero, then for any large enough `n : â„•`, `PowerSeries.coeff F n (p * (invOneSubPow F d))` equals `(hilbertPoly p d).eval (n : F)` (see `Polynomial.coeff_mul_invOneSubPow_eq_hilbertPoly_eval`).

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

@erdOne After Kevin and I agreed on what the new definition of `Polynomial.hilbert` should be, I found that the proof of `Polynomial.coeff_mul_invOneSubPow_eq_hilbert_eval` (i.e. the key property of `Polynomial.hilbert`) could be much shorter. Hence I have changed my mind and decided to include `Polynomial.coeff_mul_invOneSubPow_eq_hilbert_eval` in this pull request.

Thanks a lot for your work on this!

maintainer merge

:v: FMLJohn can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12125242634/job/33804767899)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12125242634/job/33804767166)
I think it would be better to get this result in this PR as well, to make sure that this is actually the right definition.

> I think it would be better to get this result in this PR as well, to make sure that this is actually the right definition.

I have already proved the statement in the Visual Studio Code of my computer, so I can guarantee that the definition has no problem. But the proof is very long. I'm afraid that if I also include the proof in this PR, then it may not be so easy to be merged to Mathlib 4. I plan to include the proof of the statement in some other PR.

But that is only my own opinion. I'm not sure if my plan is good. What's your opinion?
Please make a separate PR dependent on this one. That one may eventually be split but the reviewers can have a fuller picture

> Please make a separate PR dependent on this one. That one may eventually be split but the reviewers can have a fuller picture

I have created a new PR #19404 in which I have proved the key property of Hilbert polynomials. I have also marked #19404 as dependent on #19303.

> I think it would be better to get this result in this PR as well, to make sure that this is actually the right definition.

As I have already created #19404 dependent on this PR, which proves the key property of the Hilbert polynomial, may I mark this conversation as `resolved`?
I wonder whether you can more API if you define the product as `(ascPochhammer S _).comp (X + _)` or `(ascPochhammer S _).taylor _` instead

> I wonder whether you can more API if you define the product as `(ascPochhammer S _).comp (X + _)` or `(ascPochhammer S _).taylor _` instead

Thank you! I have changed the definition into `(d.factorial : â„š)â»Â¹ â€¢ ((ascPochhammer â„š d).comp (X - (C (k : â„š)) + 1))`, and consequently the proof of `preHilbert_eq_choose_sub_add` has become significantly shorter!
Can you add a new lemma instead of changing the old one?
Are you sure we want the old lemma? It's never used, and it was only added (by the author) last month. The new version looks much better...

> Can you add a new lemma instead of changing the old one?

I feel that the new theorem I have created is good enough to replace the old one.
What are these changes about? Should you be shaking the file rather than announcing you're not shaking it?

> What are these changes about? Should you be shaking the file rather than announcing you're not shaking it?

I'm not sure. After I pushed my work for the first time, the CI was not successful and the error message said that I needed to remove some unused imports. But after I removed the "unused" imports, my file stopped compiling. So I recovered the "unused" imports and ran `lake exe shake --update` as advised, and my PR passed the CI.

Most of this module docstring is nothing to do with what is in the file. Also, the docstring does not follow the guidelines for module docstrings https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html at all. Here is a suggestion for a better module docstring. 

```
/-!
# Hilbert polynomials

In this file, we formalise the following statement: given any `p : â„¤[X]` and `d : â„•`, there exists
some `h : â„š[X]` such that for any large enough `n : â„•`, `h(n)` is equal to the coefficient of `Xâ¿`
in the power series expansion of `p/(1 - X)áµˆ`. This `h` is unique and is called the
Hilbert polynomial of `p` and `d` (`Polynomial.hilbert p d`).

## Main definitions

* `Polynomial.hilbert p d`. If `p : â„¤[X]` and `d : â„•` then `Polynomial.hilbert p d : â„š[X]`
  is the polynomial whose value at `n` equals the coefficient of `Xâ¿` in the power
  series expansion of `p/(1 - X)áµˆ`

## TODO

* Prove that `Polynomial.hilbert p d : â„š[X]` is the polynomial whose value at `n` equals the
coefficient of `Xâ¿` in the power series expansion of `p/(1 - X)áµˆ`

* Hilbert polynomials of graded modules.
-/
```

Also, it is not clear to me why you restrict to `p : â„¤[X]` when clearly `p : â„š[X]` would work just as well. In fact why not do `p : k[X]` for `k` any field?

> Most of this module docstring is nothing to do with what is in the file. Also, the docstring does not follow the guidelines for module docstrings https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html at all. Here is a suggestion for a better module docstring.
> 
> ```
> /-!
> # Hilbert polynomials
> 
> In this file, we formalise the following statement: given any `p : â„¤[X]` and `d : â„•`, there exists
> some `h : â„š[X]` such that for any large enough `n : â„•`, `h(n)` is equal to the coefficient of `Xâ¿`
> in the power series expansion of `p/(1 - X)áµˆ`. This `h` is unique and is called the
> Hilbert polynomial of `p` and `d` (`Polynomial.hilbert p d`).
> 
> ## Main definitions
> 
> * `Polynomial.hilbert p d`. If `p : â„¤[X]` and `d : â„•` then `Polynomial.hilbert p d : â„š[X]`
>   is the polynomial whose value at `n` equals the coefficient of `Xâ¿` in the power
>   series expansion of `p/(1 - X)áµˆ`
> 
> ## TODO
> 
> * Prove that `Polynomial.hilbert p d : â„š[X]` is the polynomial whose value at `n` equals the
> coefficient of `Xâ¿` in the power series expansion of `p/(1 - X)áµˆ`
> 
> * Hilbert polynomials of graded modules.
> -/
> ```
> 
> Also, it is not clear to me why you restrict to `p : â„¤[X]` when clearly `p : â„š[X]` would work just as well. In fact why not do `p : k[X]` for `k` any field?

I have figured out a way to generalise my work to any field `F` with `CharZero F`, but I'm not sure if the generalised version of my codes will still fit well with @jjaassoonn's work in #9819? In his statement of the Hilbert-Serre Theorem, the polynomial `p` in the expression `p/(1 - X)áµˆ` is assumed to be in `â„¤[X]`. Then I guess I need to find some way to let Lean know that `â„¤[X]` is a subset of `â„š[X]`.
You can just `Polynomial.map` it into `â„š[X]`

> You can just `Polynomial.map` it into `â„š[X]`

OK I have pushed the generalised version of my codes.

My guess is that you are making life very hard for yourself with this definition. You already have the result when `p = 1` from your previous work. Call this polynomial h_d. Now the general polynomial for p=sum a_n X^n is just sum a_n * h_d(X-n) and that's it. There's no need to split into cases or to split on the number of times (X-1) goes into p. A cleaner definition will make for cleaner proofs.

> My guess is that you are making life very hard for yourself with this definition. You already have the result when `p = 1` from your previous work. Call this polynomial h_d. Now the general polynomial for p=sum a_n X^n is just sum a_n * h_d(X-n) and that's it. There's no need to split into cases or to split on the number of times (X-1) goes into p. A cleaner definition will make for cleaner proofs.

The reason I have written the definition by dividing into different cases is that later we will have a theorem (that can be accessed in #19404):
```
theorem natDegree_hilbert (p : â„¤[X]) (d : â„•) (hh : hilbert p d â‰  0) :
    (hilbert p d).natDegree = d - p.rootMultiplicity 1 - 1 := ...
```
which specifies the degree of any non-zero Hilbert polynomial. If I don't write the definition into cases, then I'm afraid that the proof of `natDegree_hilbert` would be more complicated.

This proof (due to Yael) is nicer:

```suggestion
-- This needs to go in the right place, e.g. near `ascPochhammer_nat_eq_ascFactorial`
theorem ascPochhammer_nat_eq_natCast_ascFactorial (S : Type*) [Semiring S] (n k : â„•) :
    (ascPochhammer S k).eval (n : S) = n.ascFactorial k := by
  norm_cast
  rw [ascPochhammer_nat_eq_ascFactorial]

theorem preHilbert_eq_choose_sub_add (d k n : â„•) (hkn : k â‰¤ n):
    (preHilbert F d k).eval (n : F) = (n - k + d).choose d := by
  have : ((d ! : â„•) : F) â‰  0 := by norm_cast; positivity
  calc
  _ = (â†‘d !)â»Â¹ * eval (â†‘(n - k + 1)) (ascPochhammer F d) := by simp [cast_sub hkn, preHilbert]
  _ = (n - k + d).choose d := by
    rw [ascPochhammer_nat_eq_natCast_ascFactorial];
    field_simp [ascFactorial_eq_factorial_mul_choose]
```

I'm not 100% sure that this is the same definition, but here's what I'm proposing:
```lean
/--
Given `p : F[X]` and `d : â„•`, the Hilbert polynomial of `p` and `d`.
If `p/(1-t)^d` is the PoincarÃ© series of a graded module `M` then
`hilbert p d` is the Hilbert polynomial of this module.
-/
noncomputable def hilbert (p : F[X]) (d : â„•) : F[X] :=
  âˆ‘ i in p.support,
  (p.coeff i) â€¢ preHilbert F (d - 1) i

lemma hilbert_zero (d : â„•): hilbert (0 : F[X]) d = 0 := by simp [hilbert]

-- is this true?
lemma hilbert_succ (p : F[X]) (d : â„•) : hilbert (p * (X + 1)) (d + 1) = hilbert p d := sorry
```
and hopefully this definition of `hilbert` is (a)  the same as what you wrote above and (b) easier to work with?

> I'm not 100% sure that this is the same definition, but here's what I'm proposing:
> 
> ```lean
> /--
> Given `p : F[X]` and `d : â„•`, the Hilbert polynomial of `p` and `d`.
> If `p/(1-t)^d` is the PoincarÃ© series of a graded module `M` then
> `hilbert p d` is the Hilbert polynomial of this module.
> -/
> noncomputable def hilbert (p : F[X]) (d : â„•) : F[X] :=
>   âˆ‘ i in p.support,
>   (p.coeff i) â€¢ preHilbert F (d - 1) i
> 
> lemma hilbert_zero (d : â„•): hilbert (0 : F[X]) d = 0 := by simp [hilbert]
> 
> -- is this true?
> lemma hilbert_succ (p : F[X]) (d : â„•) : hilbert (p * (X + 1)) (d + 1) = hilbert p d := sorry
> ```
> 
> and hopefully this definition of `hilbert` is (a) the same as what you wrote above and (b) easier to work with?

I have just noticed that this new definition is not correct. Suppose `p` is not divisible by `1 - X` and `d = 0`, then `p * (invOneSubPow F d)` will be a polynomial so we want `hilbert p d` to be the zero polynomial. However, according to our new definition, `hilbert p d = âˆ‘ i in p.support, (p.coeff i) â€¢ preHilbert F (d - 1) i = âˆ‘ i in p.support, (p.coeff i) â€¢ preHilbert F 0 i = âˆ‘ i in p.support, (p.coeff i) â‰  0`, where the second equality holds by the definition of the `-` operation on `â„•`, and the inequality holds because `p` is not divisible by `1 - X`.

So I have come up with the following idea:
```
noncomputable def hilbert (p : F[X]) (d : â„•) : F[X] :=
  if d = 0 then 0
  else âˆ‘ i in p.support, (p.coeff i) â€¢ preHilbert F (d - 1) i
```
This may not look as beautiful as we originally expected, but it is the best idea I can come up with now.

What do you think? @erdOne

> I'm not 100% sure that this is the same definition, but here's what I'm proposing:
> 
> ```lean
> /--
> Given `p : F[X]` and `d : â„•`, the Hilbert polynomial of `p` and `d`.
> If `p/(1-t)^d` is the PoincarÃ© series of a graded module `M` then
> `hilbert p d` is the Hilbert polynomial of this module.
> -/
> noncomputable def hilbert (p : F[X]) (d : â„•) : F[X] :=
>   âˆ‘ i in p.support,
>   (p.coeff i) â€¢ preHilbert F (d - 1) i
> 
> lemma hilbert_zero (d : â„•): hilbert (0 : F[X]) d = 0 := by simp [hilbert]
> 
> -- is this true?
> lemma hilbert_succ (p : F[X]) (d : â„•) : hilbert (p * (X + 1)) (d + 1) = hilbert p d := sorry
> ```
> 
> and hopefully this definition of `hilbert` is (a) the same as what you wrote above and (b) easier to work with?

Both `hilbert_zero` and `hilbert_succ` turned out to be correct, but the proof of `hilbert_succ` is not so short. As I have decided to include `Polynomial.coeff_mul_invOneSubPow_eq_hilbert_eval` (i.e. the key property of `Polynomial.hilbert`) in this pull request, and the number of lines being changed has already exceeded 100, I plan to do `hilbert_succ` in some other pull request.

Maybe you could give the example of 1/(1-X)^3 (just stating that h(n)=(n+1)(n+2)/2 in this case (if I got it right)) to explain why you need to restrict to characteristic zero. I feel like there should be a more general statement valid for all commutative rings, where h is not a polynomial but an R-linear combination of binomial coefficients. However I am not sure that we have such a concept in mathlib yet. @loefflerd did this get introduced?
Mathlib has a notion of a `BinomialRing`, which is a ring in which `r (r - 1) .. (r - n + 1)` is divisible by `n!` for all `r : R`. This was formalised by @ScottCarnahan. Scott: any thoughts?

In principle, this statement could be refined using something like the ring of integer-valued polynomials (not formalized), which is generated as a subring of `Q[X]` by `\binom{X}{n}` (not formalized), and is also the universal commutative binomial ring on one generator (not formalized). I suppose we would have to generalize "integer" to "some fixed binomial subdomain of `F`" here. Anyway, we're not particularly close at this time.
I have a definition for integer valued polynomial and some basic properties at [here](https://jjaassoonn.github.io/DimensionTheory/docs/DimensionTheory/IntegerValuedPolynomial.html)
Now it is clear that what we discuss here is beyond the scope of this pull request. I will close this conversation.

I am concerned that "the Hilbert polynomial of a polynomial" is not standard usage in the literature. For me, it's a graded module which has a Hilbert polynomial (or a coherent sheaf on a projective scheme). So if you "steal" the name `Polynomial.hilbert` to be a function on polynomials, what are we going to call the actual Hilbert polynomial? Hmm, maybe something like `GradedAlgebra.Polynomial.hilbert`? or something? But there will still be namespace clashes if the namespace is open. This is really the Hilbert polynomial of a rational function. Maybe `RatFunc.Polynomial.hilbert` is a better name, so we can avoid these problems later?

> I am concerned that "the Hilbert polynomial of a polynomial" is not standard usage in the literature. For me, it's a graded module which has a Hilbert polynomial (or a coherent sheaf on a projective scheme). So if you "steal" the name `Polynomial.hilbert` to be a function on polynomials, what are we going to call the actual Hilbert polynomial? Hmm, maybe something like `GradedAlgebra.Polynomial.hilbert`? or something? But there will still be namespace clashes if the namespace is open. This is really the Hilbert polynomial of a rational function. Maybe `RatFunc.Polynomial.hilbert` is a better name, so we can avoid these problems later?

I have already changed `Polynomial.preHilbert` into `RatFunc.Polynomial.preHilbert` and `Polynomial.hilbert` into `RatFunc.Polynomial.hilbert`. So may I resolve this conversation now?

```suggestion
For any field `F` and natural numbers `d` and `k`, `Polynomial.preHilbert F d k` is defined as
```
Is it also true that `Polynomial.preHilbert F d k` is equal to `Polynomial.hilbert` of something? Perhaps you should mention that too.

Oh come on, have mercy on the people who will have to refactor the proof when it breaks! There is no reason to use any semicolons, bytes are cheap. I really don't like `rw [show something with a three line proof in the middle of the rewrite, which uses more rewrites]`, just `have h :=` the thing you want to rewrite, prove it, and `rw [h]`, it's much easier to read. Similarly surely `exact Eq.symm <| (some lemma with nontrivial inputs)` would just be better written as `apply`ing the lemma and then solving all the intermediate goals. Furthermore, `le_trans (le_natDegree_of_ne_zero <| mem_support_iff.1 hs) (le_of_lt hn))` seems to be used 4 times! This sort of proof will randomly break one day and then it will be the job of the poor person who has to fix it to unravel this mess.
[NB Fangming (who's at my university) and I just had an offline discussion about how to tidy this proof up; he has a much more comprehensible version incoming]
`k` and `n` should be implicit because you have `hkn`.

```suggestion
lemma hilbert_poly_zero (p : F[X]) : hilbert p 0 = 0 := rfl
```
Can you add `hilbert_poly_succ` and the fact that it is `F`-linear?
I have added `hilbert_poly_succ`. I will add the fact that it is `F`-linear in another PR.

I suggest removing this from the namespace, so that Hilbert polynomials will be `Polynomial.hilbert`.
But I'm happy to hear counterarguments!

@kbuzzard and I suggest that the definition shouldn't be `Polynomial.hilbert`. This is because the thing I am constructing is not the Hilbert polynomial of some graded module. Rather, it is more like "the Hilbert polynomial with respect to some polynomial", but that does not exist in literature. See the comment: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19303#discussion_r1864399802.

What has a Hilbert polynomial? A graded algebra, a graded module over that graded algebra, a projective scheme, a coherent sheaf on that projective scheme. I thought it was a bit arrogant to "claim" `Polynomial.hilbert` for this arguably auxiliary notion, which was why I suggested it went in `RatFunc` because it's all about writing down a polynomial whose value at $n$ is the coefficient of $X^n$ in a certain rational function $P(X)/(1-X)^d$.
I would suggest `RatFunc.hilbertPoly` instead, because `RatFunc.Polynomial.hilbert` is quite long.

> I would suggest `RatFunc.hilbertPoly` instead, because `RatFunc.Polynomial.hilbert` is quite long.

Yeah I feel that this is a great idea!

Otoh, the Hilbert polynomial of a projective scheme could be `Scheme.hilbert` or `Scheme.hilbertPoly`.
So I don't think the arrogance of `Polynomial.hilbert` has to be a problem.

I would be happy with `Polynomial.hilbertPoly` or `RatFunc.hilbertPoly`. I was initially imagining `Scheme.Polynomial.hilbert` and was going to suggest `Polynomial.Polynomial.hilbert` but this sets off a linter! I also was a bit unsure about what would happen after `open Polynomial` :-)
I guess `Polynomial.hilbertPoly` would be something we can all agree on. So may I just take `Polynomial.hilbertPoly` to be the final name?
bors d+

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory/Polynomial/HilbertPoly): the definition and key property of `Polynomial.hilbertPoly p d` for `p : F[X]` and `d : â„•`, where `F` is a field.

Thanks a lot for your work on this!
